skill.name: reviewing-code
skill.description: Use when reviewing code changes, checking PRs, or evaluating code quality.
skill.summary: Use when reviewing code changes, checking PRs, or evaluating code quality.
skill.author: BPSAI

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation and review templates. No executable code, network requests, filesystem access, or command execution capabilities are present. The bash commands shown are example prompts for the user to execute manually, not automated scripts.

content.value_statement: Reviewing code manually can miss issues and produce inconsistent feedback. This skill provides a structured review workflow with categorized findings, quick audit commands, and standardized output format for consistent, thorough code reviews.
actual_capabilities: Organizes findings into Must Fix, Should Fix, and Consider categories
Provides quick bash commands to find debug statements and TODOs
Checks for hardcoded values and missing test coverage
Verifies type hints and docstrings on public interfaces
Detects potential secrets in code changes
Generates structured review summaries with verdicts
limitations: Does not execute tests or linting automatically
Does not access external APIs or services
Cannot modify code - only provides recommendations
Requires user to run git commands manually

use_cases.title: PR feedback
use_cases.description: Review pull requests with categorized findings and actionable suggestions

use_cases.title: Quality gates
use_cases.description: Enforce coding standards across team contributions systematically

use_cases.title: Self-review
use_cases.description: Review your own changes before submitting for faster feedback cycles

prompt_templates.title: Quick PR review
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the reviewing-code skill to review the changes between main and HEAD. Focus on code quality, potential bugs, and adherence to project patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Security scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the secret detection checks from the reviewing-code skill on the current changes. Report any findings.

prompt_templates.title: Test coverage review
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the reviewing-code skill to verify that new functionality has adequate test coverage. Check for mocked external services.

prompt_templates.title: Full review with git
prompt_templates.prompt: Review all changes using git diff main...HEAD. Apply the full review output format with summary, categorized findings, positive notes, and verdict.

output_examples.input: Review the changes in this pull request for quality and adherence to project patterns
output: ### Summary: Solid implementation with minor improvements needed

best_practices: Run linting and tests before starting review for faster feedback
Use the categorized format to help authors prioritize fixes
Always note positive aspects to reinforce good practices
anti_patterns: Reviewing without a structured format leads to inconsistent feedback
Skipping the security check for secrets in new code
Not verifying test coverage for new functionality

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It provides prompts and templates the AI uses during code reviews.

faq.question: Does this skill run tests automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance and prompts. Users must run bpsai-pair ci or bpsai-pair validate manually.

faq.question: Can this skill modify code?
faq.answer: No. This skill only analyzes code and provides recommendations. It does not write or modify any files.

faq.question: Is my code data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill. It processes code locally through the AI and does not send code to external services.

faq.question: How is this different from linters?
faq.answer: Linters catch syntax and style issues. This skill catches design, architecture, and quality concerns that require human judgment.

faq.question: Can I customize the review criteria?
faq.answer: Yes. Edit SKILL.md to add project-specific checks. The format remains the same but criteria can be adapted.
